title: Donald Trump's false claim about the cost of illegal immigration
text: In a renewed attempt to get Democrats to approve the money for his border wall, President Donald Trump claimed that the border wall would quickly push itself using a simple concept. Trump originally promised that Mexico would pay for the wall, but now says that the United States can afford to use savings that would come from preventing illegal migration. It is difficult to identify a difficult number on the cost of illegal migration, because there are limited data on the population living illegally in the United States. However, many immigration experts told Polyte Factor that they were not aware of any study linking migration losses or costs to $250 billion per year. And the biggest estimate we found is not even half of Trump's confirmation. It is not quite clear where Tramp's assessment comes from Trump, who has already touched upon the country's financial burden of illegal migration. During the 2016 presidential campaign, he claimed that "illegal migration costs our country more than $113 billion a year." That was mostly wrong. His recent allegation more than doubled the figures he claimed two years ago; most of the unauthorized population estimates remain at around 11 million. In a report issued in September 2017, the Right-wing Union for American Migration Reform estimated that the federal, state and local costs of more than 12.5 million people in the United States were illegally estimated at about $135 billion per year. Taking into account their tax contributions, the Group stated that the overall economic impact of illegal migration was about $116 billion per year (an increase from $113 billion in 2013). The Federation seeks to reduce legal and illegal migration to the United States, and its cost estimates tend to be higher than other relevant studies. In general, its conclusions have been criticized for relying on inaccurate estimates and general assumptions. Alex Nowaraste, an immigration policy analyst at the Liberal Cato Institute, said that the Veer 2017 report was "fat flaw." It reduced the number of migrants' tax revenues, increased the number of illegal immigrants in the country, counted millions of American citizens as illegal residents in the United States, and used a method to estimate the financial costs "rejection by all economists working on the subject." Without accurate data on the unauthorized migrant population, researchers usually identify characteristics based on responses to surveys that do not require permission. Why is it not possible for illegal immigration savings to cover the cost of the wall "in two months" that Trump claimed that the $25 billion border wall would pay itself within two months, under a scenario where illegal migration costs $250 billion a year. In general, the total cost of a full border wall is unclear. However, the real problem is to compare the costs of constructing a one-time border wall with the annual costs of net government benefits paid in excess of taxes received. "Building a wall that doesn't magically remove the already unauthorized immigrants in the country," said Ryan D. Edwards, a research partner at the Berkeley Population Centre and coordinator of a curriculum at the Berkeley University Department of Data Sciences, in an e-mail. "Only deportation does." The Trump claim also overlooks the complexities of Congressional appropriations and the reasons for the reluctance of many Democrats to finance the wall. Democrats say the wall is too expensive. They also say that there are other ways to secure the border, including the use of technology control and an increase in the number of border patrol personnel. In February 2017, a study from the Centre for Migration Studies, which prefers low levels of migration, analysed data from the national academies of science, engineering and medicine. The study examined data on the potential level of education of migrants arriving illegally across the border and its estimated financial impact. "If a border wall prevents between 160,000 and 200,000 illegal crossings (excluding slopes) in the next 10 years, it will be sufficient to pay for the estimated costs of the wall of between $12 and $15 billion," the analysis said. The expected savings are based on an average lifetime financial burden of approximately $75,000 for a person illegally across the border, but not for his or her children born in the United States. Some of the caveats noted by the analysis: the population of illegal immigrants in the United States includes persons who exceed their visa; the southern border wall will not address this issue. • A large share of the net financial costs of illegal migration lies at the state and local levels, yet the construction of a border wall would be a federal cost. It should also be noted that some of the federal costs included in some estimates of irregular migration include expenses associated with education and health care - it is uncertain whether these specific funds will be transferred to pay for the border wall. "Our country loses $250 billion a year on illegal migration, not including the terrible flow of drugs. The highest border security, including the wall, is $25 billion. He pays himself in two months." The White House did not provide data or any other information supporting the Trump evaluation. Many economists and immigration experts said that they were not aware of any report that the figure was $250 billion. It is difficult to determine the exact cost of illegal migration, but even higher estimates are much lower. Also, Trump's claim that the $25 billion border wall will pay for itself in two months is not supported by the facts either. Trump's claim is inaccurate. We assess it wrong.
